messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Musashi's sword NSR, Bad Joke
messages.msgSnippet: Sorry guys, just feeling the Christmas cherr! Uh. I mean...hey how do they say that in Japanese? Merry Ho Ho to all! Will be in NYC for Christmas. ...
messages.messageBody:
Sorry guys, just feeling the Christmas cherr! Uh. I
mean...hey how do they say that in Japanese? Merry Ho
Ho to all! Will be in NYC for Christmas.
--- Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:

> Yes, spanking monkeys. Hahahahahaha!!
>
>
>
> Gordon

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: Or is that back-handed. By the way guys, only four more shopping days until Christmas (three here), so its probably time to think about going out and buying
messages.messageBody:
Or is that back-handed. By the way guys, only four more shopping days until
Christmas (three here), so its probably time to think about going out and
buying that auto emergency repair kit for the woman (women) in your life.
I'm planning on picking mine up any day now. So, Merry Christmas, dudes!!



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontochicken [mailto:rick@...]
Sent: Tuesday, December 21, 2004 1:26 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Musashi's sword




--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@s...>
wrote:
> Well, it seems clear - lefties are superior!!

Okay, well, that explains it. No wonder all the "left-handed
compliments" for Gordon's "Kanabo treasures". Hahahaha!!!

NC ;o)

messages.subject: Re: Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: ... Well of course we are :-) As a kid, i was fully ambidextrous. I would write to the middle of the page with my left hand, then change hands and continue to
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@s...>
wrote:
> Ken,
>
>
>
> Well, it seems clear - lefties are superior!!
>


Well of course we are :-)

As a kid, i was fully ambidextrous. I would write to the middle of the
page with my left hand, then change hands and continue to the right.
In those days it wasn't seen as a good thing, so they forced me to
choose a hand. So now i am left handed, but do most sports with my
right hand, and sometimes forget which hands to hold a knife and fork
with. I would think that lefties are far more ambidextrous than right
handed people.
Nice to shave each side of the face with the appropriate hand :-)
As for Muslim customs..I wouldn't know. I use the umm..appropriate
methods. But don't try and shake hands with your left hand if the
person is Muslim...even if you are carrying boxes with your right.
Trust me...the looks will kill you. Haha.

Brian

messages.subject: Re: Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: ... Okay, well, that explains it.  No wonder all the left-handed compliments for Gordon s Kanabo treasures .  Hahahaha!!! NC  ;o)
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@s...>
wrote:
> Well, it seems clear - lefties are superior!!

Okay, well, that explains it. No wonder all the "left-handed
compliments" for Gordon's "Kanabo treasures". Hahahaha!!!

NC ;o)

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: Ken, Well, it seems clear - lefties are superior!! Gordon ... From: Kenneth Wilson [mailto:kdw21620@yahoo.com] Sent: Tuesday, December 21, 2004 10:13 AM To:
messages.messageBody:
Ken,



Well, it seems clear - lefties are superior!!



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Kenneth Wilson [mailto:kdw21620@...]
Sent: Tuesday, December 21, 2004 10:13 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword



Gordon,

I'm the same way, except when it comes to bowling and
darts which I'm never sure which hand to use (good
thing I don't do either normaly). I know in Certain
countries, like in Africa, the left hand is the
bathroom hand. you must take item in right and place
in left. Kids in school are smacked with rulers
and/or other punishment if they don't abide. That
being said, lefties are obviously smarter because they
have the ability to use both sides of the brain while
righty's have just one dominent side (the left). Even
in Rocky, he didn't want the champ to fight a south
paw. I recall a few times on one of the internet
lists some people having mounted swords for a lefty.
I wonder how that plays given the traditionalist
nature of martial arts/ sword teaching?

Ken
--- Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:

> What I meant was, as in my own case, I use my left
> hand for eating, writing
> and using small tools like scissors, but I play all
> sports with my right
> hand. I do not think that your typical right-handed
> person does that.
>
>
>
> Gordon
>
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: apedraza@...
> [mailto:apedraza@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, December 21, 2004 9:00 AM
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
>
>
>
>
> Gordon,
>
> >I might add that to the best of my knowledge there
> is no such thing as an
> entirely left-handed person. Left-handed individuals
> either due to nurture
> or nature seem to do some things with the right-hand
> and others with the
> left and sometimes able to use both for the same
> thing.<
>
> By that criteria, there are no entirely right-handed
> people, either,
> barring amputees or people with equivalent medical
> conditions. After
> all, my left hand/arm doesn't hang useless at my
> side. I use it for
> lots of things.
>
> Best Regards,
>
> Andres Pedraza
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Gordon Robson [mailto:robsongo@...]
> Sent: Monday, December 20, 2004 6:34 PM
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
>
>
> Hi John,
>
>
>
> If you refer to the Tokyo National Museum's
> publication on Uchigatana
> Koshirae, you will note several Tensho period mounts
> arranged for wear
> on
> the right side. There is some question as to whether
> or not they were
> for
> wear with the cutting edge down. I don't know of any
> illustrations
> showing
> right handed wear. I might add that to the best of
> my knowledge there is
> no
> such thing as an entirely left-handed person.
> Left-handed individuals
> either
> due to nurture or nature seem to do some things with
> the right-hand and
> others with the left and sometimes able to use both
> for the same thing.
>
>
>
> Gordon
>
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: John Lissenden
> [mailto:docliss@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, December 21, 2004 12:10 AM
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
>
>
>
> To inject a slightly more serious note into the
> smugness of your
> 'leftie'
> members ...
>
> Do any members KNOW if left-handedness was extant
> among early Japanese
> swordsmen. I have never, personally, seen
> illustrations of samurai
> wearing
> their swords on the right side, and it is not
> inconceivable that they
> were
> trained at an early age to use their swords in the
> conventional manner.
> The
> only advantage in being left handed is, surely, its
> comparative rarity
> and
> strangeness to a right-handed opponent.
>
> Interestingly, I have in my collection (WAY
> 386.27.ex Gardiner
> collection)
> an unsigned, shakudo fuchi-gashira, attributed to
> Hirata Harunari This
> has
> an ishime surface, with takaramono in a shippo of
> coloured enamels
> within
> gold cloissons. The ura surface of the fuchi has
> had an additional
> takaramono added in gold lacquer, and this may
> possibly be to facilitate
> its
> wearing on the right side by presenting a more
> decorative surface. I
> can
> think of no other possible explanation for this
> modification.
>
> John L.
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been
> removed]
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Sponsor
>
>
>
> ADVERTISEMENT
>
>

>
oups/S=1705019059:HM/EXP=1103641805/A=2495202/R=0/SIG=11evjk50a/*http:/www.n

>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: indeed, us lefties are a clever bunch, I even mix my sports up between left and right Rich ... [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
messages.messageBody:
indeed, us lefties are a clever bunch, I even mix my sports up between
left and right

Rich



Gordon Robson wrote:

> What I meant was, as in my own case, I use my left hand for eating,
> writing
> and using small tools like scissors, but I play all sports with my right
> hand. I do not think that your typical right-handed person does that.
>
>
>
> Gordon
>
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: What I meant was, as in my own case, I use my left hand for eating, writing and using small tools like scissors, but I play all sports with my right hand. I do
messages.messageBody:
What I meant was, as in my own case, I use my left hand for eating, writing
and using small tools like scissors, but I play all sports with my right
hand. I do not think that your typical right-handed person does that.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: apedraza@... [mailto:apedraza@...]
Sent: Tuesday, December 21, 2004 9:00 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword




Gordon,

>I might add that to the best of my knowledge there is no such thing as an
entirely left-handed person. Left-handed individuals either due to nurture
or nature seem to do some things with the right-hand and others with the
left and sometimes able to use both for the same thing.<

By that criteria, there are no entirely right-handed people, either,
barring amputees or people with equivalent medical conditions. After
all, my left hand/arm doesn't hang useless at my side. I use it for
lots of things.

Best Regards,

Andres Pedraza

-----Original Message-----
From: Gordon Robson [mailto:robsongo@...]
Sent: Monday, December 20, 2004 6:34 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword


Hi John,



If you refer to the Tokyo National Museum's publication on Uchigatana
Koshirae, you will note several Tensho period mounts arranged for wear
on
the right side. There is some question as to whether or not they were
for
wear with the cutting edge down. I don't know of any illustrations
showing
right handed wear. I might add that to the best of my knowledge there is
no
such thing as an entirely left-handed person. Left-handed individuals
either
due to nurture or nature seem to do some things with the right-hand and
others with the left and sometimes able to use both for the same thing.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: John Lissenden [mailto:docliss@...]
Sent: Tuesday, December 21, 2004 12:10 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword



To inject a slightly more serious note into the smugness of your
'leftie'
members ...

Do any members KNOW if left-handedness was extant among early Japanese
swordsmen. I have never, personally, seen illustrations of samurai
wearing
their swords on the right side, and it is not inconceivable that they
were
trained at an early age to use their swords in the conventional manner.
The
only advantage in being left handed is, surely, its comparative rarity
and
strangeness to a right-handed opponent.

Interestingly, I have in my collection (WAY 386.27.ex Gardiner
collection)
an unsigned, shakudo fuchi-gashira, attributed to Hirata Harunari This
has
an ishime surface, with takaramono in a shippo of coloured enamels
within
gold cloissons. The ura surface of the fuchi has had an additional
takaramono added in gold lacquer, and this may possibly be to facilitate
its
wearing on the right side by presenting a more decorative surface. I
can
think of no other possible explanation for this modification.

John L.
